question: In mouse models of experimental autoimmune myocarditis, does loss of interferon-gamma or interferon-gamma receptor signaling (via knockout or antibody depletion) increase disease severity and mortality compared with wild-type mice? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: METHODS AND RESULTS We showed that IFN-gamma receptor-deficient mice (IFN-gammaR(-/-)) on a BALB/c background immunized with a peptide derived from cardiac alpha-myosin heavy chain develop severe myocarditis with high mortality.
content.source_2: Myocarditis resolved more rapidly in IFN-gammaR(-/-) mice than in wild-type controls, with inflammation subsiding by the second week and no evidence of persistent disease.
content.source_3: Lack of IFN-gamma due to either depletion with an antibody or a genetic deficiency exacerbated myocarditis.
content.source_4: CONCLUSIONS Our data indicate that IFN-gamma promotes lethal autoimmune myocarditis by suppressing inducible nitric oxide synthase and sustaining pathogenic T-cell responses.
